subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today, I'd
like to talk about libel and humiliation.
This is an experience that not everybody
is privileged to go through. For
those of us who have had that privilege,
it's really not much of an honor. In fact,
it's the opposite of an honor or a
privilege. But, because most of you
viewing these video monologues must
share some of my interests in the
paranormal, you're all in a sense vulnerable,
because the very notion of the
paranormal engenders fear and anger in
other people, and they have an urge to
attack you and to do so viciously. It
will happen from time to time. There
are people who feel entirely self
justified that it is perfectly
appropriate, as far as they're concerned,
to be rude and nasty to people who in
their view are promoting dangerous
superstitions. Now, in my case, working to
get a doctoral diploma in
parapsychology at the University of
California, and in fact, now more than
35 years later, the only one in
the world, you can imagine that there was
opposition. In fact, the opposition
was really vicious. I had a professor of
statistics who heard about my degree
program and wrote to me saying he would
be interested in seeing some valid
statistical research in the area of
parapsychology. So, I foolishly invited
him to join my doctoral committee at
Berkeley. It soon became clear that
this particular professor considered
himself a hatchet man. As far as he was
concerned, all of my efforts were totally
and irrevocably incompetent.
In fact, as far as he was concerned, it
was so awful that he didn't have to
offer a single criticism. All he had to
do is say this is completely
incompetent. This went on for years.
It drove me crazy and actually even made
me sick. Finally, I complained to the
dean of the graduate division who said,
"Yes, this is out of bounds. And next time
he says that your work is totally
irredeemably incompetent, all you have to
do is ask him why, as you have done.
If he refuses to answer, as he has done
so many times in the past, we'll remove
him from your committee." And that's
exactly what happened, he got removed
from my committee. But then he decided
to collaborate with the Amazing Randi
from The Committee for the Scientific
Investigation of the Claims of the
Paranormal, which frankly is a misnomer
because these people conduct almost zero
scientific investigations but do many PR
stunts. They worked underhandedly to
collaborate with Psychology Today
magazine and in October of 1980
published an article saying that
Mishlove probably didn't really get this
doctoral degree, but if he did, rest
assured, the man is incompetent and the
degree is worthless. All of a sudden
I found myself publicly libeled. What
I discovered is that the people who I
regarded as my community of support, my
friends in parapsychology, the various
parapsychological groups and
organizations with which I was
affiliated, all of a sudden had to step
back because they were afraid that my
reputation, damaged as it was at that
point, would now damage their's. So, they
took a wait-and-see attitude, which
really harmed me all
the more. In fact, I am now a full member of
the Parapsychological Association and
I'm proud of it. It's an organization
affiliated with the American Association
for the Advancement of Science. It
represents the professionals in the
field of parapsychology. But after I was
liabled, my application for admission as
an associate member was declined.
That's how protective these people are.
They thought, "Gee, here's a guy from
Berkeley. Who knows how he could embarrass
us next."
So, being libeled is a very serious
business. I was quite fortunate to find
an attorney who was willing to take my
case on a contingency basis, my dear
friend, Captain Rainbow, or attorney
William Jennings, of whom I've spoken in
a previous "In Presence" segment, a
wonderful man who came to my rescue.
We fought that libel suit for six years
and we prevailed. I look back on it
now as one of the darkest periods of my
life. But the small financial reward that
came at the end of that 6 year battle
enabled me to purchase some California
real estate which has been the basis
of my wealth, really, ever since then. I
was horrified by being libeled.
It made it impossible for me to have,
really, a conventional academic career.
Would have been hard enough as it was.
There are almost none available in the field
of parapsychology. But having been
libeled completely eliminated that
possibility. And yet, it worked out for
the best. I can say that now that I'm
very comfortable financially. I'm doing
the work I love. I've been doing it for
many years. Who would have known? Who
would have thought that such a terrible
experience would turn out so well for me?
Now,
I bring all of this up because one of my
favorite guests on the New Thinking
Allowed series, Dr. Jason Reza Jorjani,
has also been libeled. I know he's
probably among the most controversial of
guests because of that. The poor man has
lost his academic position as a result
of the libel where he was
teaching at the New Jersey Institute of
Technology. His libel is far worse
than mine because people are now
associating him with the worst sort of
evil, Nazism. I know the man well.
I've interviewed him now, I haven't counted
exactly, but it's a large number, it may
be close to 20 at this point. He has
a good heart and a good soul and I will
be very happy to continue to interview
him over and over and over again no
matter how many people disagree with me
about that.
I have to say he's been
mischaracterized. Not that I agree with
his politics, I don't. For those of you
who know me, I've been a liberal Democrat
my entire life, and Jason has been all
over the map, politically. Surely, he
has flirted with the extreme right-wing,
with which I wish to have nothing to do.
But I can tell you this, I feel for Jason,
because he's going through what I went
through, having been libeled, having been
cut off, finding the people who are his
closest supporters are now looking at
him as somewhat a scant, wondering if his
damaged reputation is going to cast a
shadow on them. So, I know how he is
suffering. Although, I have
to say, his suffering must be far greater
than mine. They only called me
incompetent, they didn't
call me evil. But Jason is neither
incompetent nor evil. For those of
you, and I know there are many
fans of his because his video interviews
with me are amongst the most popular on
this channel. The man is brilliant. But
when the people who you rely on for a
social support system, because you're
engaged in the mutual pursuit of
controversial and unpopular ideas... Well,
in the case of parapsychology, the irony
is, these ideas are very popular with the
general public but not at all within
academic circles, where people are so
afraid of the horse laugh. The horse
laugh, that's the big weapon that the
skeptics used. Now, I'm mentioning Jason
because if any of you viewing this
program are in a position where you
could help this individual or anyone
else you know who is being libeled, I
urge you to do it, because there is a
kind of loneliness that occurs for
people who are suffering from that kind
of libel slander, public humiliation, and
insult. As far as I am concerned,
these people deserve sympathy and
support. I know you can't always
research every fine detail. How are you
going to know whether the libel was
justified or not? You may never get to
know. I can only say this. One of the
lessons I learned from my Jewish
upbringing, if I recall correctly,
the phrase is lashon hara, which is just
don't speak badly of other people, unless
you have a definite reason to do so. I
do, I make that my practice. I very rarely
have negative things to say about
anybody unless there is a real need for
the viewer or the listener to know. I
just don't like doing it. My rabbi once
said, "If you don't have something good to
say
then don't say anything at all." That's
sort of been my guiding philosophy
through life. It may be if you're looking
for me to say something nasty even when
I know things about other people, I won't
tell you unless I think you have a need
to know. So, I know there are many people
who feel perfectly justified saying
negative things about other people all
the time. It's just casual conversation
and I think it's part of normal
dinner table talk everywhere. Well,
let me ask you, what is in all of this
for you? Are you in a position to help
somebody who needs it because they've
been libeled? Or, maybe you need to think
twice about negative things that you say
about other people. I can only ask you to
ponder these things. And I'll leave you
with that thought. Once again, thank you
for being with me.
